content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:
@_WG-self-profile_ from @mw and @Wesley Wiser
Hello @T-compiler/meeting! Leave a :wave: below to show you're here :smile:
Starting off with
Announcements

• Reminder: if you see a PR/issue that seems like there might be legal implications due to copywrite/IP/etc, please let the Core team know (or at least message pnkfelix or Wesley Wiser so we can pass it along).
    • A new PR has been filed to include the Playstation Vita as tier 3 target. This comment suggests the situation could be similar to other end-of-life proprietary platforms. @Josh Triplett provided tips for an MCP
• @Hans Kratz is gathering interest around the macOS target platform and build a notification group who can respond to issues, see Zulip thread.
Having a notification group for macOS would be excellent! Please consider getting involved if you're interested.
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • "Unstable lints should be considered unknown" compiler-team#469

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "CI should exercise (subset of) tests under --stage 1" compiler-team#439 (last review activity: GH 2 months ago, zulip 1 month ago)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last review activity: GH 4 months ago, zulip 40 days)
    • "Make -Z binary-dep-depinfo the default behavior" compiler-team#464 (last review activity: about 41 days ago)

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Tracking Issue for cargo report future-incompat" rust#71249
    • "Tracking Issue for inline assembly (asm!)" rust#72016
    • "Tracking issue for #![feature(const_precise_live_drops)]" rust#73255

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Create a macos notification group" compiler-team#470
    • "Stabilize -Z strip as -C strip" rust#90058
    • "Stabilize -Z symbol-mangling-version=v0 as -C symbol-mangling-version=v0" rust#90128

• Accepted MCPs
    • "Tier 3 target proposal: x86_64-unknown-none (freestanding/bare-metal x86-64)" compiler-team#462

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Write text output files to stdout if options like -o - or --emit asm=- are provided" compiler-team#431
    • "Tracking Issue for destructuring_assignment" rust#71126
    • "Tracking Issue for relaxed struct unsizing rules" rust#81793
    • "GATs: Decide whether to have defaults for where Self: 'a" rust#87479
    • "Stabilize const_raw_ptr_deref for *const T" rust#89551
WG checkins

@_WG-self-profile_ from @mw and @Wesley Wiser (previous checkin):

The compiler can record artifact sizes (e.g. size of object files, rlibs, incr. comp. cache, etc) now and will do so by default when invoking it with -Zself-profile. The summarize tool will display these artifact sizes in a separate table. @rylev is working hard on also showing them on perf.rlo -- which turned out to be a little more tricky than expected but we'll get there :)This will be very useful for gauging the impact a PR might have on binary sizes and the like.
Thanks @rylev for working on that! I can't wait to see those measurements on perf.rlo :smile:
I guess we can go ahead and move on. If anyone has something else to announce, PM me and I'll make sure there's time at the end.
Backport nominations
T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

• "Apply adjustments for field expression even if inaccessible" rust#90508
    • fixes a P-medium rust#90483
    • nominated by @davidtwco since it's a regression on stable (comment)

Needs backport as this is a stable-to-stable regression

Seems like this should also be stable-nominated?
maybe it doesn't worth a dot release for this issue?
but well, I guess this is evaluated by release team
It's not clear to me from the issue if this affects code that successfully compiles. If this only affects code that fails to compile, I don't think a stable backport is necessary.
I guess let's continue with the assumption that the author and reviewers have better insight here.
Seems reasonable to beta backport.
Beta backport approved.
I've added the stable nomination label. Should we decide now also for that?
Let's leave a comment asking if this should also be stable nominated. From the reported issue, I don't think it hits the bar to warrant stable backport.
If it should be stable nominated, we can resolve that next week
ok, makes sense :thumbs_up: I'll comment and remove the label, leaving the decision to ppl with more context

• "Properly register text_direction_codepoint_in_comment lint." rust#90626
    • Fixes rust#90614
    • nominated by @Esteban Küber
Yeah, this looks straightforward. Backport approved.

• "Warn for variables that are no longer captured" rust#90597
    • nominated by @nikomatsakis , fixes incorrect migration that can cause subtle changes in execution order
There's a bit of refactoring in this PR which obscures the actual change.
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/90597/commits/fc8113d04e5ea4ae5c053388b503eb7013006e26
Is the commit that resolves the issue.
quite a big pr
Look at it under "ignore whitespace" for a more accurate perception
Still bigger than id like, but looks more reasonable and the changes look more mechanical
I reviewed the PR and I think the actual behavior changes are pretty small. The refactoring was necessary to cleanup the code enough to make the actual changes small.
seems important though
Seems like we're in agreement then. Beta backport approved.

• "Warn for variables that are no longer captured" rust#90597
    • see beta nomination
(same PR but for stable)
I personally don't think this is something we need to stable backport.
But I tend to be conservative with stable backports.
I can go both ways
Yeah, if someone wants to champion the backport, I won't stand in the way :smile:
Ok, let's decline the stable backport.
We release in 3 weeks at which point the beta backport will suffice.
T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

• "Show all Deref implementations recursively" rust#90183
    • discussed last week
    • waiting for feedback from T-rustdoc
What feedback does this need?
I discussed it in the meeting last week
What is the value in backporting this?
I think Felix was just unsure if we were going to try to improve the performance a bit more.
@nagisa this is fixing a regression from ~1.52
This feature has kind of been a mess since it was introduced due to all the regressions
At one point we backed it out completely and that caused even more regressions
So I would be ok with not backporting it for that reason

Joshua Nelson said:

At one point we backed it out completely and that caused even more regressions

In that users wanted the feature back or that it broke other things?
Ah, I see the comment that explains this – this feature was announced in a previous release, then backed out (?) because of bugs and now this is a fixed version?
@Wesley Wiser it broke other thinfs
Ouch :(
This was @pnkfelix 's PR - on mobile, don't have a link
If the original feature went through trains without any issues being found out, what confidence do we have that this moving through trains would help in discovering any remaining problems?
Not really :/
Or is the problem here that e.g. docs.rs uses nightly rustdoc?
The problem is that people don't notice rustdoc bugs
It took like 3 month for the regression from the initial PR to be discovered
Even though it was pretty majoe
Because people just thought the impls didn't exist, not that rustdoc was missing them
How confident are we that this won't introduce major regressions with other parts of rustdoc?
I guess we've already landed it so that's kind of moot.
Not super confident. We added tests for all the past regressions but of course that's no guarantee it won't introduce others
Well, that's good at least.
Based on the changes, this doesn't really have any impact on the compiler, it's solely rustdoc.
I'm inclined to go with the rustdoc team's decision.
Is there agreement there if this should be backported?
Ok. We don't have regular meetings but I can ping people on the PR.
Ok, let's do that if you don't mind. :smile:
(trying to get meetings setup but I only have limited time for rust and a lot of it is spent fixing regressions)
thanks @Joshua Nelson for the additional context, I had probably missed the final point of the discussion here :)
All the affected code is in rustdoc so if there's regressions, those are also going to fall to you all. So I think it really needs to be your team's call. I'm happy to sign off either way.

• "rustdoc: Go back to loading all external crates unconditionally" rust#90489
    • backport decision is waiting for rust#90489
^ that PR was approved
I would really like to backport this
People are running into it pretty much daily at work
And it's very low risk
Is this essentially a revert?
Yes
This is like the 3rd time it's been reverted
(I actually gave up on landing the original feature originally but @Vadim Petrochenkov has volunteered to look at it some)
Seems reasonable to beta-backport at least.
Oh, I forgot to add the voting emojis. One sec
Beta backport approved.

• "rustdoc: Go back to loading all external crates unconditionally" rust#90489
    • same as above
that's for stable now?
Yes, the same PR was beta and stable nominated.
would that need a general point release?
I would think so
i.e. for Rust as a whole
I think generally we try to avoid the "should we do a point release?" as that is a T-release question.
I think this should be included in any point release, but maybe doesn't need a point release on its own
But it is hard to ignore :smile:
(wish I had landed it before 1.56.1 went out, but oh well)
I'm torn. It seems great to fix if we are doing another release for some reason. But it doesn't seem to warrant a release by itself.
At the same time, I'm also hesitant about stable backporting a PR that only landed got approved 8 hours ago in nightly. Just as a general rule.
@Wesley Wiser that sounds like an argument for approving and letting t-release decide :P
If it weren't for the other point, I think I would agree.
has this landed yet?
I guess so. This really is low risk though, the only thing it breaks is https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/68427 which isn't important in practice
It sounds like you don't think this is critical enough to force a point release?
@mw no, it's waiting on bors
Umm. Probably not? Idk, I don't think there's ever been a point release for rustdoc
If this were the compiler I would definitely say it needs a point release
Ok, I think we should pass. We generally do not stable backport PRs that haven't hit nightly yet.
Or we can defer to next week
but by that point, the next release will only be 2 weeks away.
Ok, let's defer this decision.
PRs S-waiting-on-team
T-compiler

• "Wrap libraries in linker groups, allowing backwards/circular references" rust#85805
    • Discussed a while ago
    • @Josh Triplett will rework this patch to provide a separate option that enables linker groups (comment)
    • Can S-waiting-on-team be removed?
Yes, I think this is waiting on author now.
It doesn't look like anything more has changed since last week so moving on.

• "Change default panic strategy to abort for wasm32-unknown-emscripten" rust#89762
    • mentioned in a previous meeting, seems it can move forward?
    • Can S-waiting-on-team be removed?
I think this is waiting on Felix to review/approve.
ok. does it need to be further discussed? it's also I-nominated
I think we've decided we can move forward with this.
I'll post a note.
OK, sounds good
Oldest PRs waiting for review
T-compiler

• "Add codegen option for branch protection and pointer authentication on AArch64" rust#88354 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • last comment is paging @nagisa
This just got reassigned so I don't think we need to do anything at this time.

• "Check for duplicate attributes." rust#88681 (last review activity: about 59 days ago)
    • last comment is paging @Vadim Petrochenkov but review can be reassigned
so I guess also this one counts as reassigned, right?
I could re-assign back to me but I'm not sure when I'll be able to review.
we can still circle back on this later in the next meeting(s)
Yeah, let's give petrochenkov some more time to respond. If not, I'll take it back.
Ok, I'm going to move forward in the interest of time.
Issues of Note
Short Summary

• 0 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 79 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 55 of those are unassigned
  • 1 P-critical, 5 P-high, 3 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 2 P-high, 2 P-medium, 1 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 2 P-critical, 48 P-high, 84 P-medium, 11 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable
@aaron1011 or I can review it, I think
P-critical

T-compiler

  • No P-critical issues for T-compiler this time.
Always nice to see :heart:

T-rustdoc

  • "Index out of bounds when running cargo doc in rustc_metadata/src/creader.rs" rust#84738
    • old issue reprioritized as P-critical by T-rustdoc
    • since 1.56 it breaks doc builds for some crates) (note: this comment)
    • under scrutiny by T-rustdoc
^ this is the backported PR we talked about

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

• "Incremental compilation fails in all cases on SystemZ (s390x)" rust#90123
    • going to be closed by rust#90403 (beta-accepted)
Under control

• "regression: rustc suggests .as_ref() at incorrect location and other spans have regressed" rust#90286
    • confusing wrong diagnostic
    • @pnkfelix self-assigned
I looked at the above some time back... The span situation is suboptimal, either this or another incorrect suggestion will always happen unless we add another ast span, iirc. Not high prio though.
Looks like a revert was suggested. We should decide soon if we want to do that. This is going to hit stable in 3 weeks.
Let's move on for now.

• "DWARF info for static vars in lib crates has stopped being produced reliably in LTO builds" rust#90357
    • @pnkfelix self-assigned
I know Felix has been looking into this. I think we can leave him to handle that unless he says otherwise.

• "warn(must_not_suspend) started being raised incorrectly when moving from stable to nightly" rust#90459
    • currently unassigned
    • should be fixed by rust#89826 (it's on master and beta-accepted)
Beta-accepted PR so this seems under control.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • "Undefined reference to getauxval in function init_have_lse_atomics when compiling to nightly aarch64-unknown-linux-musl" rust#89626
    • unassigned, but:
    • fixed by libc#2272
    • and rust#90527
Performance logs

triage logs for 2021-11-09

Largely a positive week despite taking a significant performance hit from turning on incremental compilation verification for a subsection of the total queries that the compiler does in order to more quickly catch bugs in incremental compilation. Luckily optimizations in bidi detection brought large performance improvements.

Triage done by @rylev.
Revision range: 6384dca100f3cedfa031a9204586f94f8612eae5..eee8b9c7bafade55981d155dae71657f1cc55a22

2 Regressions, 4 Improvements, 4 Mixed; 1 of them in rollups
29 Untriaged Pull Requests
45 comparisons made in total

Regressions

Implement RefUnwindSafe for Rc<T> #87467

  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 1.1% on full builds of cargo)
  • Unsurprising regression in one instance of a rustdoc run since get_auto_trait_impls has bad algoritmic complexity. This issue is being tracked somewhat here.

Enable verification for 1/32th of queries loaded from disk #90361

  • Very large regression in instruction counts (up to 6.3% on incr-unchanged builds of coercions)
  • Allows for verification of incremental compilation results to more easily catch bugs (which have unfortunately been a bit too common in the past).
  • As noted in the PR this is a regression of at most 7% on coercions opt incr-unchanged, and typically less than 0.5% on other benchmarks (largely limited to incr-unchanged).
  • The PR author and reviewer reviewed the regression impact and it was deemed acceptable.

Improvements

  • Optimize bidi character detection. #90559
  • Fix ICE when rustdoc is scraping examples inside of a proc macro #90583
  • Replace some uses of vec.drain(..) with vec.into_iter() #90655
  • rustdoc: Cleanup clean::Impl and other parts of clean #90675

Mixed

rustdoc: Add DocVisitor and use it where possible #90475

  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -0.8% on full builds of serde)
  • Small regression in instruction counts (up to 0.5% on full builds of webrender)
  • The regressions have already been justified, but in short the improvements outweigh the regressions, and the code is much cleaner as a result.

Improve error when an .rlib can't be parsed #88368

  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -0.3% on full builds of externs)
  • Small regression in instruction counts (up to 0.5% on incr-unchanged builds of helloworld)
  • It was pointed out that this could be simply due to a different binary layout impacting performance.
  • When taking into account significance factor, the improvements outweigh the regressions, and so it's likely not worth it to investigate deeper.

Rollup of 4 pull requests #90695

  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -0.5% on full builds of deeply-nested-async)
  • Small regression in instruction counts (up to 0.3% on incr-unchanged builds of html5ever)
  • Nothing jumps out as a possible cause for this but luckily the perf changes in question are small.

Don't destructure args tuple in format_args! #90485

  • Large improvement in instruction counts (up to -4.0% on incr-unchanged builds of inflate)
  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 1.3% on incr-patched: println builds of html5ever)
  • The regressions seem to be coming in expand_crate which might be impacted by this change. However, nothing stands out immediately as a definite cause for concern.
  • Left a comment for the author and reviewer to ask if they have an ideas before we investigate more.
Nominated Issues

T-compiler

T-compiler

• "Tracking issue for plugin stabilization (plugin, plugin_registrar features)" rust#29597
    • nominated by @Josh Triplett, asks in comment: "what's still using plugin support?"
I'm not personally aware of anything. If you know of something, please leave a comment in the issue.
We're out of time.
I guess we will get to the rest of the list next week.
I don't see anything that looks urgent there.

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
Thanks for attending. Have a great rest of your week everyone! :wave:
Thanks for running the meeting, @Wesley Wiser !

Draft for next week's agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/uQjEgFIiRpy04QXxKDnRjA

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @_WG-async-foundations_ by @nikomatsakis and @tmandry
  • @_WG-traits_ by @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey
